Award.AbstractNarration:
The aim of this project is to further the study of random geometric graphs. This subject has grown out of applied problems, with the first questions about the way fluids seep through porous media. More recently, many questions about random geometric graphs have been prompted by the study of large scale electronic and communication networks. The basic model of random geometric graphs was proposed by Gilbert over fifty years ago: take points randomly in the plane according to a Poisson point process of intensity 1, and join two whenever they are within a distance r of each other. The main question Gilbert asked is the following: for what values of r do we obtain an infinite connected component? Surprisingly, even after fifty years, only rather poor upper and lower bounds are known for the critical value of r. Some properties of this Gilbert model are known, but many other questions still remain unanswered. The proposed project considers some of these questions, and many other questions about related models of random graph inspired by both percolation theory and large scale communication networks.

Random geometric graphs can be used to model many large scale networks that exist in real life, such as the internet, social networks, and are particularly suited to the modeling of large scale sensor and transceiver networks. As electronic devices become smaller and cheaper, it is now not uncommon to have very large networks of interconnected devices. Modeling the behavior of these networks is becoming more and more important, and the analysis of the behavior of these networks when they become extremely large is becoming increasingly relevant in real world applications. The research proposed will aid the understanding of the properties of these large scale networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to further the study of random geometric graphs. The study of random graphs, and in particular random geometric graphs has a long history, although relatively little was proved until relatively recently. The subject has grown out of applied problems. Originally many questions were related to percolation of fluids through porous media, although more recently many problems have been prompted by the study of large scale electronic networks. As an example of the first, about 50 years ago Gilbert proposed the following simple model. Take points randomly in the plane and join two points whenever they are within a distance r of each other. The question is, for what values of r do we obtain an infinite connected component? Even for this simple question, the critical value of r for which an infinite component exists is poorly known, with upper and lower bounds differing by a substantial factor. Some properties of this ‘Gilbert model’ are known, but many other questions still remain unanswered. This project considered some of these questions, and many other questions about related models of random mathematical structures inspired by both percolation theory and large scale electronic networks. This research project is in an active area of mathematics and is at the forefront of research in this area. Over thirty refereed scientific papers and book chapters were published by the PIs during the three years of this project. Many of the problems worked on required new mathematical techniques for their solution that will hopefully be applicable to many other problems.

The research project has had several broader impacts. Firstly, it has provided excellent training of graduate students for their future careers in academia, education, or in industry. More than ten graduate students have obtained their Ph.D.s during this three year project under supervision of the PIs. Secondly, it has promoted the subject area to a wide audience, in seminars, colloquia, and conferences worldwide. Thirdly, the objects of study do have some applicability outside of mathematics. The random graphs considered are often used to model sensor and transceiver networks. As electronic devices become smaller and cheaper, it is now not uncommon to have very large networks of interconnected devices. Modeling the behavior of these networks is becoming increasingly important, and the analysis of the large scale limit of these networks is becoming increasingly relevant in real world applications as these networks become ever larger in size. Although most of the questions we studied do not have immediate real world applications, some are likely to be applicable in the future.
